speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Earlier today the Federal Open Market Committee announced a ½ percentage point reduction in the target range for the federal funds rate, bringing that range to 1 to 1¼ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I took this action to help the U.S. economy keep strong in the face of new risks to the economic outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The fundamentals of the U.S. economy remain strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate has been near half-century lows for well more than a year, the pace of job gains has been solid, and wages have been rising.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These strong labor market conditions have underpinned solid household spending, which has been the key driver of economic growth over the past year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the time of our FOMC meeting in January, prospects for continued economic growth remained favorable, and we judged that monetary policy was well positioned to support that outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since then, the spread of the coronavirus has brought new challenges and risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The virus has afflicted many communities around the world, and our thoughts and prayers go out to those who’ve been harmed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The outbreak has also disrupted economic activity in many countries and has prompted significant movements in financial markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The virus and the measures that are being taken to contain it will surely weigh on economic activity both here and abroad for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are beginning to see the effects on the tourism and travel industries, and we are hearing concerns from industries that rely on global supply chains.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The magnitude and persistence of the overall effects on the economy, however, remain highly uncertain, and the situation remains a fluid one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Against this background, the Committee judged that the risks to the U.S. outlook have changed materially.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In response, we have eased the stance of monetary policy to provide some more support to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, the ultimate solutions to this challenge will come from March 3, 2020 others, particularly health professionals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can and will do our part, however, to keep the U.S.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL economy strong as we meet this challenge.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As always, our actions are guided by our congressional mandate to promote maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the weeks and months ahead, we will continue to closely monitor developments and their implications for the economic outlook, and we will use our tools and act as appropriate to support the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you, and I’ll be happy to take a few questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we’ve been carefully monitoring the situation since it first became known and waiting to see how it would evolve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think we’ve come to the view now that this—that it is time for us to act in support of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And once you reach that decision, we decided to go ahead.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So what changed, really, was, I would say, over the course of the last couple weeks, we’ve seen a broader spread of the virus—we’ve seen it begin to spread a bit here in the United States.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, for us, what really matters, of course, is not the epidemiology, but the risk to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we saw a risk to the outlook for the economy and chose to act.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think anybody knows how long it will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do know that the U.S. economy is strong, and we will get to the other side of this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I fully expect it will return to solid growth and a solid labor market as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, first question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We—we’re in active discussions with central banks around the world on an ongoing basis, as you would guess.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ve been in regular contact with central bank leaders from around the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That will continue.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Central banks are doing what makes sense in their particular institutional contexts, but we’re all talking to each other on an ongoing basis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And our action today represents what we think is the right policy for us in our particular institutional context under our domestic mandate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You saw this morning’s G-7 statement of finance ministers and governors, and I think that statement does reflect coordination at a high level in the form of a commitment to use all available tools, including health-care policy, fiscal policy, and monetary policy as “appropriate.” So, in terms of fiscal policy, again, not our role.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have—we have a full plate with monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Not our role to give advice to the fiscal policymakers, but you saw the mention in the G-7 statement—as “appropriate” as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the sense of the G-7, you know, is to—we have seven countries, obviously, and different policies, different situations, different mandates—a lot of overlap.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the sense of that is to get together as a group and say at a high level that “These are the things we’re going to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are going to use our tools—all of our tools in a strong way to—to try to support the economy.” So that’s a statement of general support.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think within that you will see actions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’ve seen our action.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think it’s up to individual countries—individual fiscal policies and individual central banks—to do what they’re going to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would think it will be—it’s possible there will be some more—more formal considered coordination as we move forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of—in terms of moving forward, I would say that we do like our current policy stance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think—we think it’s appropriate to—to support achievement of our dual-mandate goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But as I said in my—in my statement, we’re prepared to use our tools—tools and act appropriately, depending on the flow of events.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I can’t point to any one thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s always a range of things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we don’t—we don’t see any of that happening yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we are—we are thinking about what we can do should those things happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s no evidence of it yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economy continues to perform well—perform well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, we do hear concerns, particularly from those most directly exposed, but there’s nothing in that nature: Financial markets are functioning in an orderly manner and all that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think when it—when it comes to those sorts of issues, though, we will be—the supervisors will be working with banks to assure that they work with their—with their borrowers and that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I can imagine us doing those sorts of things, but it’s—those things are not upon us at the moment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, as you know, we’re in the middle of a review of all of our tools.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you go back a few meetings, we’ve talked about what our toolkit is, and we’ve put that in the minutes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But in the current context, no.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we discussed is the current stance of policy, is it appropriate—came to the view that it was appropriate to make a change and went ahead and did that today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure, I’d be glad to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the virus outbreak is something that will require a multifaceted response.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that response will come, in the first instance, from health-care professionals and health policy experts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will also come from fiscal authorities should they determine that a response is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it would be—come from many other public- and private-sector actors: businesses, schools, state and local governments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But there’s also a role for monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Monetary policy can be an effective tool to support overall economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do recognize that a rate cut will not reduce the rate of infection.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It won’t fix a broken supply chain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We get that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t think we have all the answers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we do believe that our action will provide a meaningful boost to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: More specifically, it will support accommodative financial conditions and avoid a tightening of financial conditions which can weigh on activity, and it will help boost household and business confidence.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s why you’re seeing central banks around the world responding as they see appropriate in their particular institutional context.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on your first question, we’re always going to set monetary policy at a given time in a way that we think best serves our dual-mandate goals, and it’s as simple as that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we’ll—if we get to a place where we think it’s an appropriate time to change March 3, 2020 the stance of monetary policy, we won’t hesitate to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would also say that it’s—it’s very Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL important that people understand that we will always make our decisions based on the best thinking we have, based on our—what we learned from our outreach to businesses, nonprofits, educational institutions that we get every cycle through the Reserve Banks, and the best analysis, the best research.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re always going to make our decisions in the interests of the American people to carry forward and try to achieve the mandates that Congress has given us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re never going to consider any political considerations whatsoever.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will not do that, and it’s very important that the public understand that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re—we are hearing—I would just say, the effects are at a very early stage.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you are hearing concerns from people—for example, in the travel business or the hotel business and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s—that’s what you are hearing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you don’t see things showing up in actual data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You do see them showing up in, sort of, sentiment forecast indicators and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect that will continue.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will probably grow.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s one of the reasons why we’ve come to the view that it would be appropriate for us today to move to support the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s what we’ve done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks very much.
